pros: Great product and owns the market
cons: None that I can think of

summary: This company is not what they seem.
pros: They pay well, provide meals & snacks in hubs.
cons:
-Inaccessible leadership, even at director & manager levels
-Confusing secrecy. There are problems with the way you are doing things, but we won't tell you exactly what the problems are, we'll occasionally change what the problems are, and we won't tell you where the feedback is coming from. 
-Retaliatory behavior. If you complain about the wrong person, even if that person is showing blatant disrespect or even illegally harassing you, their friends in management will retaliate
-Lack of organization. Projects can't get done because you can't get a consensus on getting them done. 
-Zero trust. You're not able to do your job unless multiple people approve every aspect. There is micromanaging at a level I've never seen before.
-There is a serious communication issue. You will not get the information you need or be told where what little information you have is coming from. You will then be told that you need to communicate better.

pros:
Fully remote 
Good products

cons:

pros:
- The people & culture
- Great product & market leader in the space
cons:

pros: Good environment to work in
cons: Not much. Decent experience to work

summary: Great people, interesting product, relentless grind
pros:
- Kindest, smartest, and most talented co-workers you'll ever get to work with
- Interesting challenges to solve, which keep you on your toes always pushing the boundaries of your work
- Nice SF office, decent location
- Generous monthly stipend for caregivers and parents, which can be used for extracurricular activities, babysitters, educational resources, and more
- Personable CEO who makes an effort to know and acknowledge people in the company
- The company is profitable and doing well!
- A rocket ship that is adored by many
cons: The company benefits and perks come at a price. The grind is real and is celebrated by execs. Be prepared to put in long hours, especially as major events like Config approach. Burnout is a common occurrence due to the intense workload. It's challenging to maintain a work-life balance and truly disconnect, as the company's ambitious nature demands constant focus on launching new features, updates, and hosting events at a rapid pace. These relentless working conditions are unsustainable in the long run. Compounding the issue, opportunities for career growth and upward mobility are limited, leaving employees feeling stagnant and facing a career plateau. You need to be extra proactive in advocating for yourself or else you'll just be swept away in the grind.

summary: Love the work and the people
pros: Great culture with collaboration and respect, amazing product, good leadership, lots of optimism for the future. I used to dread going to work in my past companies on Monday morning. At Figma, I find the projects and team mates interesting and want to go and work in the morning. Figma is also fully remote, which gives me more time to spend with family compared to being at the road in the Bay Area traffic. Coming from FANG companies, I found work place politics to be close to zero. Very high percentage of people try to do what is right for Figma, which is very refreshing.
cons: No major complaints at all. When we see growing pains, leadership is generally quick to address them. Even though company is fully remote, if you want face time with others, the Hubs are not very close. For instance, in Bay Area, I have to commute to SF to see team mates. Luckily I do it only once or twice a month, which works fine. Would love to see more Hubs in the East Bay.

pros: Great company with a bright future ahead. The product is in a league of it's own, the people are smart, and the culture is great.
cons: Management struggles to make decisions and to maintain focus on important initiatives. Compensation is below average considering the businesses performance and there is no clear career trajectory for most employees.

summary: Innovative, warm, and welcoming people, competitive pay, and great benefits!
pros: Teams are always working to keep employees informed of upcoming changes and to maintain a positive company culture. Catered breakfast and lunch Monday - Thursday. Variety of snacks and beverages available all week long. Lots of good effort from the BEI team to create a culture of belonging.
cons: Teams can be very distributed across the globe. Other teams have been able to connect through regular offsites, but with my small, international team, the opportunities to fully connect and meet my team members in London and Tokyo has been very limited.

pros: Company is very well positioned, coworkers are very strong and humble
cons: Career advancement can be challenging

pros: great perks, cool product, industry disruptor - lots of smart people on PDE. Dylan Field is a genuine person.
cons: The expectations are not realistic. Globally hitting targets (or coming close to them) but that is because of 10-12 people out of 100 reps are hitting target across all segments. Most people not even hitting 70%. More focus on "activity" than what is actually working. Managers want to look good to their managers who want to look good to the CRO....everyone is afraid to say what is actually going on. Toxic, stressful work environment. Burnout rampant. Books are not quality accounts, inflexible about changing processes to include methods that would actually help us increase revenue.

pros:

pros: Great Perks. Good Pay. Vacation.

pros: People care about the product, you make something that matters.
cons: High performance culture, not bad comparatively, but definitely not a place to coast. Could be a pro tbh.

cons: Figma is a high growth startup with endless potential. However, due to the fast nature of this growth and wearing many hats, the workload and long hours could be heavy.

pros: Doing some of the best work of my career here. The company has a conspicuous lack of ego and everyone is just really good at what they do and extremely kind. Lots of opportunity to build new things, be heavily involved in product decisions, and solve hard technical problems (all at once).
cons: Company is growing really fast which comes with some tensions that any growing company has, but still coping with it some of the best I�ve seen

pros: Perks, people are amazing and overall great
cons: Eng leadership and overall is pretty clueless and over prioritized partnerships over innovation

summary: Awesome product, incredibly smart people, and lots to figure out
pros:
- This is by far the best product I've ever sold. The pure joy and excitement heard from customers truly inspires me to want to put my best foot forward. I strive to have the customer experience match the product experience. 
- People here care about their job and the people around them. From a sales Org, that can be rare in my experience. 
-Leadership cares, they know when things are tough and they honestly try and get to the root cause and figure out a solution. But as the company gets bigger this some times takes longer. 
- This job is more than just a quota, It's about wanting to better yourself and leadership constantly harps on wanting Figma to be a place we look back on and lean on all our learnings and experiences.
cons:
- Sure, quota can be tough at time. I won't lie, but show me a sales role where quota isn't a constant pain point. We're in sales and we live and die by quota. 
- Leadership has taken a lot of time to better evaluate how territories/books are cut. They have very recently adjusted our quota to not only be Net New ARR but also renewal ARR. This is a recent, and very welcomed shift, that rewards us for fighting customer churn, which previously wasn't the case.

pros: Leadership suite is very approachable. Great perks with lots of travel. Everyone is super nice and the culture is fun.
cons: Work has become a grind and burnout is common. Not a good ratio of senior to junior employees. Grew too fast and unsustainably.

summary: Run, don't walk from this sales org
pros: Bright coworkers who you can learn from, selling a top-tier product that customers adore
cons: Clearly overhired for a product whose pricing/packaging/use cases don't align with the need for a massive commercial sales team. Accounts aren't high quality, and most of them are already (happily) using Figma self-service plans. Avg deal size is crazy small and all they care about is how much pipeline you're generating, even if it's fake.. would not suggest joining sales here anytime soon.

summary: Inexperienced Sales Org - CFO down to Managers
pros: They provide a ramp period of 6 months for new hires. They pay for home office setup and have great wellness benefits. But it's all to distract you from the really challenging work environment and low performance of their upstream segments.
cons: I hope I can say that the sales organization lacks a lot of experience and it shows. Upper management does not have a viable solution to improving the performance of their upstream market segments. They tried shifting courses 3 times in my short tenure.
